title: Tibet Huayu Mining provides $7 million loan for TALCO Gold and Antimony Mining Project in December 2020
description: In April 2017, Tajik Aluminium Company (TALCO or 塔铝国有公司) — a Tajik state-owned enterprise -- created a project company and wholly owned subsidiary known as CJSC TALCO Gold (“塔铝金业”封闭式股份公司). Then on December 15, 2017, TALCO and Tibet Huayu Mining Co., Ltd. (西藏华钰矿业股份有限公司) signed a joint venture agreement, in which Tibet Huayu Mining Co., Ltd. acquired a 50% ownership stake in CJSC TALCO Gold for $100 million. Tibet Huayu Mining Co., Ltd. provided a $90 million equity investment and a $10 million interest-free, long-term loan to facilitate the acquisition. The issuance of the interest-free loan was approved by Tibet Huayu Mining Co., Ltd. on January 28, 2018. Tibet Huayu Mining Co., Ltd. issued two additional loans to CJSC TALCO Gold in April 2018: a $300,000 loan (with a 5% interest rate and 5-year maturity) on April 4, 2018 and a $10 million loan (with a 5% interest rate) on April 6, 2018.   On May 25, 2018, CJSC TALCO Gold (“塔铝金业”封闭式股份公司) — a special purpose vehicle and 50/50 joint venture between Tibet Huayu Mining Co., Ltd. (西藏华钰矿业股份有限公司) and Tajik Aluminium Company (TALCO or 塔铝国有公司) — announced plans to construct a $135 million mining and processing plant in the Aini District in Sughd Region on the Konchoch deposit. The plant was expected to produce 1.5 tons of gold and 16,000 tons of antimony annually. At the time, preliminary estimates suggested that the Konchoch deposit contained 55 tons of gold, 44 tons of silver, 184 tons of mercury, 268,000 tons of antimony and 205,000 tons of fluorite. CJSC TALCO Gold originally expected to complete the project by the end of 2019 and begin mining production in early 2020.   Construction began on June 24, 2018, and the project’s groundbreaking ceremony was attended by President of Tajikistan Emomali Rahmon. Then, on June 18, 2019, Tibet Huayu Mining Co., Ltd. issued an additional, $30 million loan to CJSC TALCO Gold (with a 6% interest rate and 5-year maturity). The June 18, 2019 loan was ‘upsized’ by $10 million (to $40 million) on November 1, 2019 and by $20 million (to $60 million) on December 28, 2019. As of June 2020, construction work at the project site was 80% complete, but the delivery of equipment produced in Finland was delayed by coronavirus-related restrictions and TALCO announced that it could take another two months to finally get it shipped and running. Then, on August 31, 2020, Tibet Huayu Mining Co., Ltd. announced that it was considering providing a loan of no more than RMB 49 million ($7.16 million) to CJSC TALCO Gold. Tibet Huayu Mining Co., Ltd. approved the issuance of an additional $7 million loan to CJSC TALCO Gold (with a 6% interest rate and 5 year maturity) on December 22, 2020. Then, on August 25, 2021, Tibet Huayu Mining Co., Ltd. agreed to issue another loan to CJSC TALCO Gold worth $20 million. All of these loans issued by Tibet Huayu Mining Co., Ltd. to CJSC TALCO Gold were apparently provided with the proceeds from a Bank of China bond issuance.   The TALCO Gold mine ultimately went into production on April 14, 2022. At the mine’s inauguration ceremony, CJSC TALCO Gold announced that it expected to produce up to 2.2 tons of gold and 21,000 tons of antimony annually, according to government officials. Then, on January 24, 2023, a trainload of mining output from CJSC TALCO Gold arrived in China.
staff_comments: 1. Talco Aluminum Company is a Tursunzoda-based state-owned company that is also partially owned Hasan Asadullozoda, the brother-in-law of President Emomali Rahmon, 2. Tibet Huayu Mining Co., Ltd. engages in the non-ferrous metal mining, mineral processing, and geological prospecting businesses. Its products include zinc concentrate, lead antimony concentrate, and copper concentrate. The company was founded on October 22, 2002 and is headquartered in Beijing, China. 3. Antimony is a flame-proof metal used in batteries. 4. The Chinese project title is 塔铝金业建设项目 or 塔吉克斯坦锑金冶炼厂or 中塔合资企业塔铝金业5000吨/天锑金采选项目. 5. As of June 30, 2022, Tibet Huayu Mining Co., Ltd. disclosed in a public filing that it had cumulatively provided loans worth $92,257,322.92 to CJSC TALCO Gold (see http://vip.stock.finance.sina.com.cn/corp/view/vCB_AllBulletinDetail.php?stockid=601020&id=8486271). This amount is inconsistent with the aggregate value of the 8 loans ($107.3 million) that Tibet Huayu Mining Co., Ltd. claims it issued to CJSC TALCO Gold between 2017 and 2021. This discrepancy warrants further investigation. 6. For Tibet Huayu Mining Co., Ltd's investment in the CJSC TALCO Gold joint venture, see linked Project ID#72667.
combined_text:
# Sector
INDUSTRY, MINING, CONSTRUCTION

# Title
Tibet Huayu Mining provides $7 million loan for TALCO Gold and Antimony Mining Project in December 2020

# Description
In April 2017, Tajik Aluminium Company (TALCO or 塔铝国有公司) — a Tajik state-owned enterprise -- created a project company and wholly owned subsidiary known as CJSC TALCO Gold (“塔铝金业”封闭式股份公司). Then on December 15, 2017, TALCO and Tibet Huayu Mining Co., Ltd. (西藏华钰矿业股份有限公司) signed a joint venture agreement, in which Tibet Huayu Mining Co., Ltd. acquired a 50% ownership stake in CJSC TALCO Gold for $100 million. Tibet Huayu Mining Co., Ltd. provided a $90 million equity investment and a $10 million interest-free, long-term loan to facilitate the acquisition. The issuance of the interest-free loan was approved by Tibet Huayu Mining Co., Ltd. on January 28, 2018. Tibet Huayu Mining Co., Ltd. issued two additional loans to CJSC TALCO Gold in April 2018: a $300,000 loan (with a 5% interest rate and 5-year maturity) on April 4, 2018 and a $10 million loan (with a 5% interest rate) on April 6, 2018.   On May 25, 2018, CJSC TALCO Gold (“塔铝金业”封闭式股份公司) — a special purpose vehicle and 50/50 joint venture between Tibet Huayu Mining Co., Ltd. (西藏华钰矿业股份有限公司) and Tajik Aluminium Company (TALCO or 塔铝国有公司) — announced plans to construct a $135 million mining and processing plant in the Aini District in Sughd Region on the Konchoch deposit. The plant was expected to produce 1.5 tons of gold and 16,000 tons of antimony annually. At the time, preliminary estimates suggested that the Konchoch deposit contained 55 tons of gold, 44 tons of silver, 184 tons of mercury, 268,000 tons of antimony and 205,000 tons of fluorite. CJSC TALCO Gold originally expected to complete the project by the end of 2019 and begin mining production in early 2020.   Construction began on June 24, 2018, and the project’s groundbreaking ceremony was attended by President of Tajikistan Emomali Rahmon. Then, on June 18, 2019, Tibet Huayu Mining Co., Ltd. issued an additional, $30 million loan to CJSC TALCO Gold (with a 6% interest rate and 5-year maturity). The June 18, 2019 loan was ‘upsized’ by $10 million (to $40 million) on November 1, 2019 and by $20 million (to $60 million) on December 28, 2019. As of June 2020, construction work at the project site was 80% complete, but the delivery of equipment produced in Finland was delayed by coronavirus-related restrictions and TALCO announced that it could take another two months to finally get it shipped and running. Then, on August 31, 2020, Tibet Huayu Mining Co., Ltd. announced that it was considering providing a loan of no more than RMB 49 million ($7.16 million) to CJSC TALCO Gold. Tibet Huayu Mining Co., Ltd. approved the issuance of an additional $7 million loan to CJSC TALCO Gold (with a 6% interest rate and 5 year maturity) on December 22, 2020. Then, on August 25, 2021, Tibet Huayu Mining Co., Ltd. agreed to issue another loan to CJSC TALCO Gold worth $20 million. All of these loans issued by Tibet Huayu Mining Co., Ltd. to CJSC TALCO Gold were apparently provided with the proceeds from a Bank of China bond issuance.   The TALCO Gold mine ultimately went into production on April 14, 2022. At the mine’s inauguration ceremony, CJSC TALCO Gold announced that it expected to produce up to 2.2 tons of gold and 21,000 tons of antimony annually, according to government officials. Then, on January 24, 2023, a trainload of mining output from CJSC TALCO Gold arrived in China.
justification: Mining project focused on gold and antimony extraction, neither of which are energy transition minerals
evidence: Project produces 2.2 tons of gold and 21,000 tons of antimony annually, no mention of energy transition minerals

title: China Eximbank agrees to suspend principal and interest payments on multiple loans in August 2020
description: On August 5, 2020, China Eximbank and the Government of Tajikistan signed a debt rescheduling (suspension) agreement. Under the terms of the agreement, the lender agreed to suspend principal and interest payments due between September 2020 and mid-2021 under multiple loan agreements. The total estimated suspension amount was $40 million. Then, in September 2020, Paris Club creditor countries agreed to provide to the Republic of Tajikistan a time-bound suspension of debt service due from May 1, 2020 to December 31, 2020.
combined_text:
# Sector
ACTION RELATING TO DEBT

# Title
China Eximbank agrees to suspend principal and interest payments on multiple loans in August 2020

# Description
On August 5, 2020, China Eximbank and the Government of Tajikistan signed a debt rescheduling (suspension) agreement. Under the terms of the agreement, the lender agreed to suspend principal and interest payments due between September 2020 and mid-2021 under multiple loan agreements. The total estimated suspension amount was $40 million. Then, in September 2020, Paris Club creditor countries agreed to provide to the Republic of Tajikistan a time-bound suspension of debt service due from May 1, 2020 to December 31, 2020.
justification: Debt rescheduling agreement with no direct environmental or energy transition impact
evidence: Debt suspension agreement, financial services focus

title: Chinese Government provides customs control equipment worth $31.5 million to Tajikistan in April 2020
description: In April 2020, the Chinese Government donated 8 units of customs control equipment worth $31.5 million to Tajikistan. The equipment was provided to contribute to the simplification of customs procedures and a reduction in the time of customs clearance.
staff_comments: 1. The exact donation date was unspecified2. The specified pieces of equipment donated were unspecified

justification: Project focuses on customs control equipment without clear environmental or energy transition impacts
evidence: Customs control equipment donation, focus on customs procedure simplification

title: Africa Growing Together Fund provides $50 million loan for Msalato International Airport Construction Project (Linked to Umbrella Project ID#36104)
description: On May 22, 2014, the African Development Bank (AfDB) and the People's Bank of China (PBOC) signed an agreement for the Africa Growing Together Fund (AGTF) (see Umbrella Project ID#36104). The purpose of this $2 billion loan facility was to finance large development projects in Africa between 2014 and 2024. The AGTF is sponsored by the PBOC and the administered by AfDB.   Then, on March 13, 2020, AGTF signed a $50 million loan agreement (ID#5050200001055) with the Government of Tanzania for the Msalato International Airport Construction Project. On the same day, the African Development Bank (AfDB) issued a $198.63 million loan (ID#2000200004672) and the African Development Fund issued an $23 million loan agreement (ID#2100150042269) to the Government of Nigeria for the same project. The borrowing terms of the AGTF, AfDB, and ADF loans were as follows: a 24-year maturity, a 5-year grace period, an interest rate of 6-month LIBOR plus a 0.9% margin, a 0.25% commitment fee, and a 0.25% management fee.   The purpose of the project is to construct a new international airport in the district Msalato for the city of Dodoma, thereby improving access, regional and international connectivity to the administrative capital city and the Central Region of the country. The scope of the project includes a passenger terminal, a runway, air navigation equipment. It also includes other related operational services, such as a fuel distribution company, water supply systems, electrical power distribution substations and a fire-fighting service. Upon completion, the airport is expected to handle at least 50,000 aircrafts and a million passengers per year, most of which will be international. The airport is expected to benefit and serve more than 200 million passengers in East Africa, as well as international trade networks, and especially business travelers and tourists. The project will also seek to improve long-term institutional capacities of the Tanzania Airports Authority (TAA), the Tanzania Civil aviation Authority (TCAA) and the Accident Investigation Bureau (AIB) in meeting international operational standards and strengthening of national regulatory oversight. The first loan disbursement took place on January 13, 2021. However, this project suffered significant delays in procurement due to the lockdown resulting from the COVID-19 pandemic. In September 2021, AFDB awarded a contract to China Jiangxi International Economic and Technical Cooperation Co., Ltd (CJIC) for the implementation of the Msalato International Airport Construction Project.
staff_comments: 1. The AfDB project identification number is P-TZ-DA0-003. 2. The project’s economic rate of return is estimated at 11.6%. 3. The all-in interest rate (1.864%) was calculated by adding an 0.9% margin to the average 6-month LIBOR rate in March 2020 (0.964%). 4. The margin of 0.9% was calculated by adding the Funding Cost Margin (unknown) to the Lending Margin (0.8%) and the Maturity Premium (0.10%)
combined_text:
# Sector
TRANSPORT AND STORAGE

# Title
Africa Growing Together Fund provides $50 million loan for Msalato International Airport Construction Project (Linked to Umbrella Project ID#36104)

# Description
On May 22, 2014, the African Development Bank (AfDB) and the People's Bank of China (PBOC) signed an agreement for the Africa Growing Together Fund (AGTF) (see Umbrella Project ID#36104). The purpose of this $2 billion loan facility was to finance large development projects in Africa between 2014 and 2024. The AGTF is sponsored by the PBOC and the administered by AfDB.   Then, on March 13, 2020, AGTF signed a $50 million loan agreement (ID#5050200001055) with the Government of Tanzania for the Msalato International Airport Construction Project. On the same day, the African Development Bank (AfDB) issued a $198.63 million loan (ID#2000200004672) and the African Development Fund issued an $23 million loan agreement (ID#2100150042269) to the Government of Nigeria for the same project. The borrowing terms of the AGTF, AfDB, and ADF loans were as follows: a 24-year maturity, a 5-year grace period, an interest rate of 6-month LIBOR plus a 0.9% margin, a 0.25% commitment fee, and a 0.25% management fee.   The purpose of the project is to construct a new international airport in the district Msalato for the city of Dodoma, thereby improving access, regional and international connectivity to the administrative capital city and the Central Region of the country. The scope of the project includes a passenger terminal, a runway, air navigation equipment. It also includes other related operational services, such as a fuel distribution company, water supply systems, electrical power distribution substations and a fire-fighting service. Upon completion, the airport is expected to handle at least 50,000 aircrafts and a million passengers per year, most of which will be international. The airport is expected to benefit and serve more than 200 million passengers in East Africa, as well as international trade networks, and especially business travelers and tourists. The project will also seek to improve long-term institutional capacities of the Tanzania Airports Authority (TAA), the Tanzania Civil aviation Authority (TCAA) and the Accident Investigation Bureau (AIB) in meeting international operational standards and strengthening of national regulatory oversight. The first loan disbursement took place on January 13, 2021. However, this project suffered significant delays in procurement due to the lockdown resulting from the COVID-19 pandemic. In September 2021, AFDB awarded a contract to China Jiangxi International Economic and Technical Cooperation Co., Ltd (CJIC) for the implementation of the Msalato International Airport Construction Project.
justification: Project focuses on airport construction and related infrastructure without clear environmental or energy transition impacts
evidence: Construction of international airport with passenger terminal, runway, and operational services; no specific energy transition components mentioned

title: Chinese Government donates medical materials worth 302,500 USD to combat COVID-19 to Tanzania in May 2020
description: On May 15, 2020, the Chinese Government donated medical materials to Tanzania to combat COVID-19. The package was worth more than 700 million TZS (around 302,500 USD). The donation includes N95 masks, surgical masks, gloves, protective shoes, protective clothing, goggles, and thermometers. This donation is a gesture of China's commitment to Tanzania, as they were the first country to lend aid during COVID-19.
combined_text:
# Sector
HEALTH

# Title
Chinese Government donates medical materials worth 302,500 USD to combat COVID-19 to Tanzania in May 2020

# Description
On May 15, 2020, the Chinese Government donated medical materials to Tanzania to combat COVID-19. The package was worth more than 700 million TZS (around 302,500 USD). The donation includes N95 masks, surgical masks, gloves, protective shoes, protective clothing, goggles, and thermometers. This donation is a gesture of China's commitment to Tanzania, as they were the first country to lend aid during COVID-19.
justification: Project is a healthcare donation with no direct environmental or energy transition impact
evidence: Medical materials donation for COVID-19 response, including masks, protective equipment, and thermometers

title: Chinese Embassy and Chinese Contractors Association in Tanzania donates TZS 150 million to Tanzania for Kilimanjaro fire fighting (Linked to Project ID#94301)
description: On October 23, 2020, the Chinese Embassy and the Chinese Contractors Association in Tanzania donated TZS 150 million to the Tanzania National Parks Authority as financial assistance for fighting the wildfire on Kilimanjaro. The donation will be used for purchasing materials and equipment to fight the fire. Wang Ke, Chinese Ambassador to Tanzania, Badiho, High Commissioner of the Tanzania National Parks Authority, Vaitala, Acting Director of the Asian and Australian Department of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs of Tanzania, and Zhang Junle, President of the Contractors Association of Chinese-funded Enterprises in Tanzania, attended the ceremony.
combined_text:
# Sector
EMERGENCY RESPONSE

# Title
Chinese Embassy and Chinese Contractors Association in Tanzania donates TZS 150 million to Tanzania for Kilimanjaro fire fighting (Linked to Project ID#94301)

# Description
On October 23, 2020, the Chinese Embassy and the Chinese Contractors Association in Tanzania donated TZS 150 million to the Tanzania National Parks Authority as financial assistance for fighting the wildfire on Kilimanjaro. The donation will be used for purchasing materials and equipment to fight the fire. Wang Ke, Chinese Ambassador to Tanzania, Badiho, High Commissioner of the Tanzania National Parks Authority, Vaitala, Acting Director of the Asian and Australian Department of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs of Tanzania, and Zhang Junle, President of the Contractors Association of Chinese-funded Enterprises in Tanzania, attended the ceremony.
justification: Project is a financial donation for emergency response and firefighting, with no direct environmental or energy transition impact
evidence: Donation for firefighting materials and equipment, emergency response focus

title: Chinese Embassy donates hand-washing devices to primary and secondary schools in Tanzania to aid in the fight against COVID-19
description: On June 25, 2020, the Chinese Embassy donated hand-washing devices to 100 primary and secondary schools in Tanzania to aid in the fight against COVID-19. The donation included: 100 hand-washing devices and 550 liters of hand sanitizer. The donation is worth 22,000,000 Tanzanian Shillings. The handover ceremony took place at the embassy and was jointly organized by the Chinese Embassy in Tanzania and the Tanzanian NGO Kawa Foundation. Wang Ke, Chinese Ambassador to Tanzania, Malangwa, Acting Administrative Secretary of the Province of Tajikistan, Mfuma, Chief Medical Officer, Kowa, Executive Director-General of the Kaowa Foundation, and representatives of the donated schools attended the ceremony.
combined_text:
# Sector
HEALTH

# Title
Chinese Embassy donates hand-washing devices to primary and secondary schools in Tanzania to aid in the fight against COVID-19

# Description
On June 25, 2020, the Chinese Embassy donated hand-washing devices to 100 primary and secondary schools in Tanzania to aid in the fight against COVID-19. The donation included: 100 hand-washing devices and 550 liters of hand sanitizer. The donation is worth 22,000,000 Tanzanian Shillings. The handover ceremony took place at the embassy and was jointly organized by the Chinese Embassy in Tanzania and the Tanzanian NGO Kawa Foundation. Wang Ke, Chinese Ambassador to Tanzania, Malangwa, Acting Administrative Secretary of the Province of Tajikistan, Mfuma, Chief Medical Officer, Kowa, Executive Director-General of the Kaowa Foundation, and representatives of the donated schools attended the ceremony.
justification: Project is focused on public health and disease prevention, with no direct environmental or energy transition impact
evidence: Donation of hand-washing devices and sanitizer to schools for COVID-19 prevention

title: Chinese Embassy donates Hospital materials worth of 30,000 Tanzanian Shillings to Tanzania Vijibweni Hospital
description: On December 2, 2020, the Chinese Embassy donated hospital materials to the Tanzania Vijibweni Hospital. The donation included wheelchairs, transport kits, hemoglobin photometers, infrared thermometers, etc. The materials are worth 30,000 Tanzanian Shillings.
